title: Erdős Problem #667: Clique Density Exponent c(p,q)
description: Is c(p,q) = lim inf log H(n;p,q)/log n strictly increasing in q, where H(n;p,q) is the largest clique guaranteed when every p-set spans ≥ q edges?

overview.historicalContext: Erdős, Faudree, Rousseau, and Schelp studied H(n;p,q), the largest clique guaranteed in n-vertex graphs where every p-set has ≥ q edges. They defined c(p,q) = lim inf log H/log n and asked whether it is strictly increasing in q. Known bounds include the Ramsey-type bounds for q = 1 and c(p, ⌊(p-1)/2⌋) ≤ 1/2.
overview.problemStatement: Is c(p,q) strictly increasing in q for 1 ≤ q ≤ C(p-1,2) + 1?
overview.proofStrategy: The formalization axiomatises H(n;p,q) with monotonicity and boundary values, then defines c(p,q) with known Ramsey bounds and the EFRS bound. The strict monotonicity conjecture is the main statement.
keyInsights: H(n;p,q) generalises Ramsey numbers by requiring q edges per p-set
c(p,1) corresponds to classical Ramsey: 1/(p-1) ≤ c ≤ 2/(p+1)
c(p, C(p-1,2)+1) = 1 trivially (every graph is complete)

sections.title: The Function H(n; p, q)
sections.summary: Axiomatisation of H(n;p,q) with monotonicity in n and q.

sections.title: Boundary Values
sections.summary: H at maximum q equals n (complete graph); H at q = 0 equals 1.

sections.title: The Exponent c(p, q)
sections.summary: c(p,q) with Ramsey bounds for q = 1, c = 1 at max q, and EFRS bound.

sections.title: Main Conjecture
sections.summary: c(p,q) is strictly increasing in q.

conclusion.summary: The formalization captures Erdős Problem 667, asking whether the clique density exponent c(p,q) is strictly increasing in the edge-density parameter q.
conclusion.implications: Strict monotonicity would show that every additional edge per p-set gives a strictly larger polynomial clique guarantee, refining the landscape between Ramsey theory and Turán-type extremal results.
openQuestions: Is c(p,q) strictly increasing in q?
What is the exact value of c(p,q) for small p and general q?
Can the EFRS bound c(p, ⌊(p-1)/2⌋) ≤ 1/2 be improved?
